text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen today I am 
making a dish that recently became super popular

in Thailand because it made an appearance 
in a certain famous television series but

that's besides the point because this dish is a 
delicious thing to make in its own right it is

something called NAmpla waan which translates to 
sweet fish sauce and it's something that we use

to dip our fruit in now I know for some of you 
the word fish sauce and fruit don't seem like

they should ever go in the same sentence but trust 
me it's so delicious that not only do we do it in

Thailand there are variations of this dip all over 
Southeast Asia and it is gonna be the thing that

saves all the fruits that you don't want to eat 
fresh you know anything that's sour or under ripe

this is the thing you want to put on it let's get 
started so it's very very easy the main ingredient

the sweet part of number one is palm sugar so just 
gonna add them all in here now it's very important

that you use palm sugar because as you can see it 
is the main flavor so any substitutes that you use

will yield a slightly different flavor okay of 
course we're gonna need some fish sauce how much

fish sauce you add will actually depend on the 
saltiness of the next ingredient that is shrimp

paste yes we're adding fish sauce and shrimp paste 
to our fruit dip it's gonna be good shrimp paste

can vary very much in saltiness so I would start 
with just 2 tablespoons of fish sauce taste it

see how it goes and you can add more afterwards 
just gonna add a little bit of water to help this

get started and all we're gonna do very easy is 
turn the heat on just low medium low until all

the sugar is dissolved and so how I did my sugar 
from the blocks how I process it initially I just

pounded in a mortar and pestle and broke it down 
to little little pieces it's a lot of chopping

so when it's a lot of palm sugar I just pound it 
ok so while that's going let's take a look at the

rest of our stuff I got two sets of dried shrimp 
here they're actually the same it's just that one

I roughly chopped so the pieces are smaller and 
then the other ones I'm gonna blitz in my coffee

grinder so it's very fine mix as well you can 
blitz everything of you all but I like just little

bits of chewiness dispersed all throughout my 
dip so now I'm gonna add this to my copy grinder

and blitz that until it's very fine just a few 
seconds and tada we got two fluffy shirt bits

and apart from that I just got some thinly sliced 
shallots and some chilies spiciness is to taste

and that is it that's all the ingredients that 
we have and now I'm just gonna wait for all my

sugar to dissolve and so it's helpful for you to 
just kind of go in and mash it with your spatula

it'll help it go a little bit faster so it's now 
completely dissolved I'm gonna turn this off oh

let the bubbles subside a little bit so I can see 
what's actually going on here there we go so what

you're gonna end up with with is something that 
seems too runny for a dip right now because it's

very hot but it will thicken up significantly 
once it cools down so in goes my dried shrimp

I'm gonna add some umami and a little bit of 
texture and body have chopped shrimp so some

people like to let this cool first before they add 
their shallot so the shallots sort of stay fresh I

actually preferred if the shallots are a little 
bit cooked down by just by the residual heat so

I've turned this off right so cuz I find otherwise 
the shallots just a little bit too pungent and

then my chili is going in and Chili's I definitely 
like to put it when it's still hot because it will

disperse the spiciness better so now definitely 
you want to taste this for balance of salty and

sweet but remember this is like melted sugar it's 
very very hot so you want to really blow on it mmm

oh it's perfect you just want like a really nice 
balance of salty and sweet and if it's your first

time making it just you might just not have any 
idea of what it should taste like in which case

what I would suggest you do is actually dip your 
fruit in it and see how it goes with your fruit

if it's too salty a little more sugar if it's 
too sweet and a little more salt so that it

all ends up being very well balanced and that's 
it how easy is that oh yeah look at that now in

terms of fruits that you want to serve with this 
classically we serve this with sour green mango

so it's very crunchy very tart so the tartness 
goes really well with the sweet and saltiness of

this dip however here I can't find sour green 
mango but I have found many other fruits that

actually work really well anything that's tart and 
firm enough then you can like hold it in your hand

so you can dip it will work so for example granny 
smith apple is my absolute go to it's crisp it's

firm its tart perfect and then here I also have 
pineapple that's way too white way too firm not

juicy enough way too tart but it's perfect for 
this dip strawberries come on like we all know

the strawberries show up so disappointing so 
many times or too firm too sour not sweet enough

perfect for an apply wine and finally I've got 
here this is just mango but it's under ripe mango

so it's a little too soft but it's hard enough 
that I think it still works so if you've got

a mango that's just you know not good enough to 
eat on its own try it with this dip as well what

should I try with this let's go with my regular 
go-to granny smith apples oh yes look at that

you want to get some shallots actually I'm gonna 
look for some dried shrimp bits there we go yeah

step is the word I want to use for this it's spicy 
salty it's an amazing amount of umami that you've

never had with fruit before you know like when 
was the last time you had fruit and umami paired

together it's so perfect like it's it's such 
if you've never seen never had it it's just

something than like what I don't really get how 
that works and I just gave this to Adam by the

way who was a very cynical of this dish to put it 
mildly and you loved that he was like this is so

surprisingly good so if you are unfamiliar with 
this concept give it a go and then write me let

me know what you think about it I'm also gonna try 
some strawberries because like tart firm crunchy

strawberries it's one of the my biggest food pet 
peeve like they always look so good at the store

and then they turn out with no flavor this is 
what you do with them this is what you do with

them chewiness from those dried shrimp you just 
gotta try it out so the recipe as always will be

on hot Thai Kitchen calm when you make it send 
me a photo and I would love to know what other

kinds of fruit you paired with you know what 
would be really good Cape gooseberries those

little things that always end up on dessert 
garnish nobody really wants to eat them coz

they're sour be perfect with this dip and if you 
haven't subscribed to the show make sure you do

so you don't miss an episode and click that little 
bell icon as well so you get a notification when I

post a new video if you love the show and you 
want to support us check out our patreon link

which is in the description below and I will see 
you next time for your next delicious type you

won't try it mm-hmm is good right hmm sarcastic 
even though it has shrimp juvett that's crazy
